title: Subdomain takeover of blog.snapchat.com
vulnerability_information:
#Overview
The ANAME for blog.snapchat.com, which redirects to snapchat-blog.com, was pointing to tumblr for Snapchat's blog.  This blog had been expired or had removed the CNAME claim.  Adding "snapchat-blog.com" to the custom domain setting on tumblr allowed takeover of this subdomain.

#Repro Steps
1) Visit http://blog.snapchat.com
Result: Blog registered by my account "jreynoldsdev" displays title "Hello Snapchat - Jake Reynolds"

#Suggested Fixes
The best fix would be for Snapchat's tumblr blog to reclaim this CNAME.  For resolution contact me and we can coordinate switching the domain name back under your control.

If you have any further questions please feel free to reach out.

Thanks,
Jake
vulnerability_information_html:
Overview

The ANAME for blog.snapchat.com, which redirects to snapchat-blog.com, was pointing to tumblr for Snapchat's blog. This blog had been expired or had removed the CNAME claim. Adding "snapchat-blog.com" to the custom domain setting on tumblr allowed takeover of this subdomain.

Repro Steps

1) Visit http://blog.snapchat.com
Result: Blog registered by my account "jreynoldsdev" displays title "Hello Snapchat - Jake Reynolds"

Suggested Fixes

The best fix would be for Snapchat's tumblr blog to reclaim this CNAME. For resolution contact me and we can coordinate switching the domain name back under your control.

If you have any further questions please feel free to reach out.

Thanks,
Jake

activities.message: For further clarification this domain was actively pointing to http://snapchat.tumblr.com on September 24th.  This was verified by [google cache](http://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:ghJPPAubkL8J:snapchat-blog.com/post/146998839575/introducing-memories+&cd=3&hl=en&ct=clnk&gl=us) although the cache may have been recrawled by the time you view this.
activities.markdown_message: For further clarification this domain was actively pointing to http://snapchat.tumblr.com on September 24th. This was verified by google cache although the cache may have been recrawled by the time you view this.

activities.message: I would also like to follow up and say I am not trying to publicly disclose this vulnerability before you have the chance to fix it.  Due to the nature of the exploit I did have to claim the subdomain, so users who visit http://blog.snapchat.com will see the landing page.  I will remove it at your request.
activities.markdown_message: I would also like to follow up and say I am not trying to publicly disclose this vulnerability before you have the chance to fix it. Due to the nature of the exploit I did have to claim the subdomain, so users who visit http://blog.snapchat.com will see the landing page. I will remove it at your request.

activities.message:
Hi @jreynolds - thanks for disclosing this to us. Acknowledging the same. 

Can you either remove it or redirect to https://snap.com/news

thanks,
-Subhash.

activities.message:
The page now redirects to the new blog.

It looks like you also removed the ANAME on blog.snapchat.com so let me know when you are available and I'll remove the CNAME claim so you can recover it quickly.

activities.message:
@jreynolds - thanks once again for disclosing this issue to us. If you can provide your email address, I will put you in touch with my colleagues who can assist in the take over of the tumblr account.

Our VRP panel sets h1 awards and it meets during the week. So please bear with us on that front.

thanks,
-Subhash.

No worries about the timing for bounties.

-Jake

activities.message: Just for clarity in terms of this report I have been connected with Sebastian and Garrett from the Snapchat team over email.  They responded very quickly and helpfully.  The Tumblr custom domain name claim has been removed from my account and the ANAME for snapchat-blog.com is no longer pointing to Tumblr's IP address.
activities.markdown_message: Just for clarity in terms of this report I have been connected with Sebastian and Garrett from the Snapchat team over email. They responded very quickly and helpfully. The Tumblr custom domain name claim has been removed from my account and the ANAME for snapchat-blog.com is no longer pointing to Tumblr's IP address.

activities.message: @jreynolds Sorry about the delay. We are hoping to have a decision this week. Thank you for your patience.
activities.markdown_message: @jreynolds Sorry about the delay. We are hoping to have a decision this week. Thank you for your patience.

activities.message:
Hi @jreynolds 

Thanks for assisting in claiming the domain ownership back from you.

We strongly feel that the Proof of Concept could have been handled by you in a much safer manner than you did. Taking over the domain was enough to prove the existence of the vulnerability. If you wanted to take it a step further, you could have put up a page with "test" on it. Your approach however, was drastic and went against responsible disclosure guidelines. 

From the eligibility section of our [rules page](https://hackerone.com/snapchat), please note the following items:
 - Disclose the vulnerability report responsibly to us. Public disclosure or disclosure to other third parties - including vulnerability brokers - before we addressed your report forfeit the reward.
 - Demonstrate care in reproducing the vulnerability.

We understand from your earlier comments that you were not attempting to publicly disclose the issue; however, directly modifying our blog in production inherently caused a public disclosure resulting in us needing to take down the blog. Google search results for "Snapchat blog" showed your modifications as well, requiring us to rush to correct them.

While you were professional and courteous in working with us to disclose this issue, and we definitely appreciate you writing in and working with us to resolve it, unfortunately our panel has decided, for the reasons above, that your report will not qualify for a bounty. For future reports, if you are unsure about how to create a proof of concept, please reach out to us so we can assist with the same.

Regards,
Subhash
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @jreynolds

Thanks for assisting in claiming the domain ownership back from you.

We strongly feel that the Proof of Concept could have been handled by you in a much safer manner than you did. Taking over the domain was enough to prove the existence of the vulnerability. If you wanted to take it a step further, you could have put up a page with "test" on it. Your approach however, was drastic and went against responsible disclosure guidelines.

From the eligibility section of our rules page, please note the following items:

  • Disclose the vulnerability report responsibly to us. Public disclosure or disclosure to other third parties - including vulnerability brokers - before we addressed your report forfeit the reward.
  • Demonstrate care in reproducing the vulnerability.

We understand from your earlier comments that you were not attempting to publicly disclose the issue; however, directly modifying our blog in production inherently caused a public disclosure resulting in us needing to take down the blog. Google search results for "Snapchat blog" showed your modifications as well, requiring us to rush to correct them.

While you were professional and courteous in working with us to disclose this issue, and we definitely appreciate you writing in and working with us to resolve it, unfortunately our panel has decided, for the reasons above, that your report will not qualify for a bounty. For future reports, if you are unsure about how to create a proof of concept, please reach out to us so we can assist with the same.

Regards,
Subhash

activities.message:
While I accept your decision and appreciate your transparency I would like to clarify from my point of view.  I used the PoC on the webpage so that you would have a direct link to what was happening.  I did not want Snapchat noticing your webpage routing through my blog and think a black hat actor was under control of the blog.

If I had set up javascript on the page to auto-redirect, users would have noticed suspicious web activity linked to my account name, and not have known it was in the name of security research.  In my opinion this was the quickest and least suspicious way to get the issue fixed, but I understand there are other ways it could have been done.

Thank you for clarifying your decisions and I hope you understand the actions I took as well.

Thanks,
Jake
activities.markdown_message:
